columns.text: In this problem, we need to indicate which factors affect the length of the credit period and to answer why the upper limit of the length of the credit period is exactly the length of the buyer’s operating cycle.

The most important factors that affect the length of the credit period are the customer's inventory period and the duty cycle. However, there are several other factors that affect the credit period, such as the perishability and value of collateral, consumer demand, cost, profitability and standardization, credit risk, account size, competition and customer type.

It is important that the length of the buyer’s operating cycle does not exceed the upper bound on the length of the credit period. If that were to happen, then the seller would provide financing to the buyer for aspects of the buyer's business that are outside their contractual purchase and sale of goods. So, in that case, the buyer has a credit from the seller even after the goods are resold, and the buyer can use that credit for other purposes. To avoid such abuse, the upper bound on the length of the credit period is the length of the buyer’s operating cycle.

textbook.authors: Bradford D. Jordan, Randolph W. Westerfield, Stephen A. Ross
